Dear RICHARD WATKINS:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 10/19/2023 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed
corrective action plan, all social service workers who
have children placed in the home shall be notified there
is a corrective action plan and what is required of the
foster parent in that plan.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed required a corrective action plan.
There was inadequate documentation to confirm the social worker with children in
the home had been notified of the terms of the corrective action plan for the
caregivers.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(4) Before completion of the written report required by
subrule (6) of this rule, an agency shall provide the
foster parent with a verbal summary of the preliminary
findings at the conclusion of the evaluation.
One of the two special evaluations reviewed indicated in the completed special
evaluation report that a verbal summary of the findings of the special evaluation
had not been completed with the caregivers.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for
each child and parent or parents, as follows:

(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed had at least one updated
service plan that was completed outside the time frame required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(5) An agency shall involve the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the
foster parent’s role in assisting the agency in carrying
out the plan.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed did not have a Parent Agency
Treatment Plan to indicate all the required parties were involved in the
development of of the treatment plan.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(6) Service plans shall be signed by the social services
worker and the social services supervisor.
Two of the six current foster child records reviewed did not include the required
signatures for at least one updated service plan.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy
shall, at a minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and
any treatment required for each child who is 4
years of and and older, including both of the
following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be
completed not more than 90 calendar days after
placement.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated an initial dental
examination had not been completed within the time frame required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both of the following shall
be documented before a change in placement:

(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
The record for one foster child who was returned to a parent but is still under
supervision did not include the change in placement documentation required by
this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
(4) If an emergency change in placement is necessary,
than all of the documentation required in subrules (2)
and (3) of this rule shall be in the child’s record within
14 calendar days after the change in placement.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed indicated the foster child had
a change in placement 6/28/2023 and the change in placement documentation for
this change was not completed or could not be located.
This is a repeat noncompliance from the interim evaluation completed
1/30/2023, with a CAP completed 6/27/23.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans
for each child and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from
the home.
One of the six current foster child records reviewed had an initial service plan that
was completed outside the time frame required by this rule.
FOM 722 – 06 B Family Team Meeting
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.

Five of the six current foster child records reviewed had at least one incident
where an FTM was either not completed or not documented as required by this
standard.
This is a repeat noncompliance from the interim evaluation completed
1/30/2023, with CAP accepted on 6/27/23.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided regarding current expectations related to
the maintenance of Medical Passports and the use of the CWLM helpdesk to
provide assistance as needed.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• None
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency had a corrective action plan for the interim evaluation completed in
January 2023. Areas identified in noncompliance as a part of the interim
evaluation were Rules 327(5)(d), 205(8)(b), 327(6)(c), 418(2)(a), 405(4), and FOM
722-06B. The corrective action plan was approved 6/27/2023. Areas identified as
repeat noncompliance as part of the renewal evaluation were Rule 405(4),
418(2)(a), and FOM 722-06B.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was a review of the approved Corrective
Action Plan for the interim evaluation completed in January 2023 and a
comparison of agency data with key performance indicators.
Financial Overview
The completed audit for the 2022 year indicated adequate financial support for the
continuation of services for children and families.

Staff and Youth Interviews
Child Welfare Staff participated in entrance and exit conferences. Discussions
were generally positive and there were no concerns identified.
Youth interviews with the analyst were positive with no concerns identified. There
were no safety alerts identified.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency facility is well maintained, and the storage of files/records was
consistent with compliance for licensing rules.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts identified. Comments from caregivers and youth
indicated appropriate support services are being provided.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
